items.content_html:
Day 96 and we‚Äôre looking at iPad-friendly APIs for the first time.

I‚Äôll be honest‚ÄîI had not tried running any of our previous apps in the iPad simulator, but now I see they were working fine the whole time. Pretty cool!

This screenshot looks absolutely chaotic. üëπ #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 94 is a review and challenge day! Graphics code can be a doozy because when you get the wrong result, it‚Äôs difficult to know what‚Äôs actually wrong in the code (or with your math). üòÖ I got some help with this one. üò¨ #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 93 was a fun walk through of using GeometryReader, including using visualEffect() and scrollTargetBehavior(). #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 92, we started a new project (our second to last!) and learned about how layout, alignment guides, and absolute positioning work within SwiftUI.

I really loved the explainer, starting from How layout works in SwiftUI. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 92, we started a new project (our second to last!) and learned about how layout, alignment guides, and absolute positioning work within SwiftUI. I really loved the explainer, starting from [How layout works in SwiftUI](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/how-layout-works-in-swiftui). #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Picking #100DaysOfSwiftUI back up, and in the home stretch at Day 91! It was a challenge day with a review quiz and an open-ended prompt to fix a couple minor bugs and add a feature.

items.title: 2024 iPhone Home Screens
items.content_html:
As the year comes to a close, I want to take a quick snapshot of what my home screens look like now so I can compare them in a year from now.

I say home screens because I use focus modes extensively to change my home screens (depending on my current focus):

Let‚Äôs go through them roughly by time of day:

Morning

Here‚Äôs what my Morning home screen looks like (in Small icon mode so it‚Äôs easier to understand with labels; I actually use Large icon mode everywhere):

Fitness

Here‚Äôs what my Fitness home screen looks like:

Work

Here‚Äôs what my Work home screen looks like:

Driving

Here‚Äôs what my Driving home screen looks like:

Personal

Here‚Äôs what my Personal home screen looks like:

Do Not Disturb

Here‚Äôs what my Do Not Disturb home screen looks like:

Evening

Here‚Äôs what my Evening home screen looks like:

Sleep

Here‚Äôs what my Sleep home screen looks like:
items.content_text:
As the year comes to a close, I want to take a quick snapshot of what my home screens look like now so I can compare them in a year from now. I say home _screens_ because I use [focus modes](https://support.apple.com/guide/iphone/set-up-a-focus-iphd6288a67f/ios) extensively to change my home screens (depending on my current focus):
Focus Mode Triggered
Morning Automatically at 4:00 AM and off either at 9:00 AM (workdays) or 12:00 PM (weekends)
Fitness Automatically when I start/stop a workout
Work Automatically at 9:00 AM on weekdays
Driving Automatically when I start/stop driving
Personal Manually when I want to be in a Focus mode
Do Not Disturb Manually whenever I need to be completely offline
Evening Automatically by 8:30 PM
Sleep Automatically when my Wind Down schedule starts
Let‚Äôs go through them _roughly_ by time of day: ## Morning Here‚Äôs what my Morning home screen looks like (in Small icon mode so it‚Äôs easier to understand with labels; I actually use Large icon mode everywhere):
## Fitness Here‚Äôs what my Fitness home screen looks like:
## Work Here‚Äôs what my Work home screen looks like:
## Driving Here‚Äôs what my Driving home screen looks like:
## Personal Here‚Äôs what my Personal home screen looks like:
## Do Not Disturb Here‚Äôs what my Do Not Disturb home screen looks like:
## Evening Here‚Äôs what my Evening home screen looks like:
## Sleep Here‚Äôs what my Sleep home screen looks like:

items.content_html: I‚Äôm so bummed that the macOS ‚Äúwidgets on your desktop‚Äù feature is so unreliable for me. I go to the trouble of setting up a bunch of widgets on my second display, only for them to disappear after some random number of restarts. Seems like a great feature but I can‚Äôt trust it. üòû
items.content_text: I‚Äôm so bummed that the macOS ‚Äúwidgets on your desktop‚Äù feature is so unreliable for me. I go to the trouble of setting up a bunch of widgets on my second display, only for them to disappear after some random number of restarts. Seems like a great feature but I can‚Äôt trust it. üòû

items.content_html: For Day 89, we learned how to detect when our app moves to the background or foreground so we could pause and restart our timer at the right moment. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 89, we learned how to detect when our app moves to the background or foreground so we could pause and restart our timer at the right moment. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 88, we built a brand new part of the app with a stack of cards and gestures for swiping them left and right to move to the next card. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 88, we built a brand new part of the app with a stack of cards and gestures for swiping them left and right to move to the next card. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 87, we learned a little bit about the Combine framework, Timer, and three accessibility settings: Differentiate Without Color, Reduce Motion, and Reduce Transparency. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 87, we learned a little bit about the Combine framework, `Timer`, and three accessibility settings: Differentiate Without Color, Reduce Motion, and Reduce Transparency. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 86, we started a brand new project and started playing with all the gesture APIs and hit testing. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 86, we started a brand new project and started playing with all the gesture APIs and hit testing. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 85 is a challenge day! The quiz was easy but the challenge took me about an hour to complete. The ‚Äúcontacted‚Äù icon, link to an edit screen, and sort options are all new. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 85 is a challenge day! The quiz was easy but the challenge took me about an hour to complete. The ‚Äúcontacted‚Äù icon, link to an edit screen, and sort options are all new. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 84, we learned how to add swipe actions to list items and show local notifications using the UserNotifications framework! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 84, we learned how to add swipe actions to list items and show local notifications using the `UserNotifications` framework! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 83 has this tidbit:

The CPU running our code doesn‚Äôt care about data types, comments, access control, and more, but if you want to write great software that is scalable, testable, and maintainable, you need to add some rules.

There‚Äôs a little piece of me that wishes we talked more about testing and maintainability. I know they‚Äôre more advanced topics that I‚Äôll learn on my own, but a man can still wish.

Today we added UI to scan QR codes and multi-item editing. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 83 has this tidbit: > The CPU running our code doesn‚Äôt care about data types, comments, access control, and more, but if you want to write great software that is scalable, testable, and maintainable, you need to add some rules. There‚Äôs a little piece of me that wishes we talked more about testing and maintainability. I know they‚Äôre more advanced topics that I‚Äôll learn on my own, but a man can still wish. Today we added UI to scan QR codes and multi-item editing. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 82 was much easier‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think there was anything new, we ‚Äújust‚Äù laid the groundwork for the new tabs and added the SwiftData pieces to store the contact info. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 82 was much easier‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think there was anything new, we ‚Äújust‚Äù laid the groundwork for the new tabs and added the SwiftData pieces to store the contact info. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Today was almost smooth sailing, learning about list row swipe actions and local/scheduled notifications, but I ran into issues with the directions for adding Swift package dependencies in Xcode.

I wrote up the issue and my fix in this issue: Day 81: No such module 'SamplePackage' #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Today was _almost_ smooth sailing, learning about list row swipe actions and local/scheduled notifications, but I ran into issues with the directions for [adding Swift package dependencies in Xcode](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/adding-swift-package-dependencies-in-xcode). I wrote up the issue and my fix in this issue: [Day 81: `No such module 'SamplePackage'`](https://github.com/twostraws/SamplePackage/issues/3) #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 80 and we‚Äôre learning about Result, image interpolation, and context menus.

This stood out to me:

Remember, context menus are by their nature hidden, so please think twice before hiding important actions in a context menu.

Undiscoverable UI might as well be no UI at all. I value explicit UI that‚Äôs easy to discover and understand. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 80 and we‚Äôre learning about Result, image interpolation, and context menus. This stood out to me: > Remember, context menus are by their nature hidden, so please think twice before hiding important actions in a context menu. Undiscoverable UI might as well be no UI at all. I value explicit UI that‚Äôs easy to discover and understand. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 79 and we‚Äôre (finally) learning about TabView, my favorite way to keep our example code around!

One actual takeaway from today: impressive that an EditButton can affect the state of a List in the same view without any explicit bindings; I‚Äôm usually cautious of ‚Äúmagical‚Äù APIs. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 79 and we‚Äôre (finally) learning about TabView, my favorite way to keep our example code around! One actual takeaway from today: impressive that an EditButton can affect the state of a List in the same view without any explicit bindings; I‚Äôm usually cautious of ‚Äúmagical‚Äù APIs. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 78, we started saving the user‚Äôs current location when they save one of the photos to the app. Easy peasy! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 78, we started saving the user‚Äôs current location when they save one of the photos to the app. Easy peasy! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 77 was a doozy of a challenge: build an entire app from scratch that imported a photo, prompted for a name, stored both somehow (I chose SwiftData), display it in a list, and show a detail view.

It was a lot of work but took me about an hour from start to finish. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: [Day 77](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/77) was a doozy of a challenge: build an entire app from scratch that imported a photo, prompted for a name, stored both somehow (I chose SwiftData), display it in a list, and show a detail view. It was a lot of work but took me about an hour from start to finish. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 76, we had a quiz and challenge: fix accessibility issues in three of our past apps.

For Cupcake Corner, I couldn‚Äôt reproduce the issue.

For iExpense, the fix was easy.

For Moonshot, there were a couple images that needed labels, but I couldn‚Äôt find any other issues. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
For Day 76, we had a quiz and challenge: fix accessibility issues in three of our past apps.

For [Cupcake Corner](https://swift.chasen.dev/2024/11/13/day-is-a.html), I couldn‚Äôt reproduce the issue.

For [iExpense](https://swift.chasen.dev/2024/11/02/day-included-a.html), the fix was easy.

For [Moonshot](https://swift.chasen.dev/2024/11/04/day-was-our.html), there were a couple images that needed labels, but I couldn‚Äôt find any other issues. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I liked Paul‚Äôs message on Day 75 of #100DaysOfSwiftUI much better:

There‚Äôs a New York lawyer called Gregory Mansfield who fights for disability rights, and he once wrote this: ‚ÄúAccessibility is not charity. Accessibility is not generosity. Accessibility is not an amenity. Accessibility is not a gratuity. You don‚Äôt bestow access ‚Äì you ensure it.‚Äù

üëè
items.content_text:
I liked Paul‚Äôs message on [Day 75](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/75) of #100DaysOfSwiftUI much better:

> There‚Äôs a New York lawyer called Gregory Mansfield who fights for disability rights, and he once wrote this: ‚ÄúAccessibility is not charity. Accessibility is not generosity. Accessibility is not an amenity. Accessibility is not a gratuity. You don‚Äôt bestow access ‚Äì _you ensure it_.‚Äù

üëè

items.content_html:
On Day 74 we‚Äôve started learning about accessibility.

I‚Äòm not a fan of how this is framed:

Tony Fadell ‚Äì the creator of the iPod at Apple ‚Äì had this to say: ‚Äúyou are defined by what you do and also by what you don‚Äôt do.‚Äù

Sure, you can skip accessibility and 90% of people won‚Äôt notice, but do you want to be defined by that? I‚Äôd wager that the answer is no.

I wish this focused on accessibility as a fundamental human right that‚Äôs needed by all of us at one point or another‚Ä¶ not just an arbitrary percentage (that is really low as well). #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: On [Day 74](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/74) we‚Äôve started learning about accessibility. I‚Äòm not a fan of how this is framed: > Tony Fadell ‚Äì the creator of the iPod at Apple ‚Äì had this to say: ‚Äúyou are defined by what you do and also by what you don‚Äôt do.‚Äù > > Sure, you can skip accessibility and 90% of people won‚Äôt notice, but do you want to be defined by that? I‚Äôd wager that the answer is _no_. I wish this focused on accessibility as a fundamental human right that‚Äôs needed by *all* of us at one point or another‚Ä¶ not just an arbitrary percentage (that is really low as well). #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 73 was a challenge day, so I had fun refactoring some of the code from the main View into a ViewModel and adding error handling. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 73 was a challenge day, so I had fun refactoring some of the code from the main View into a ViewModel and adding error handling. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Today we refactored our code to use MVVM and added ‚Äúunlock with FaceID‚Äù to this part of the app.

From Day 72:

Tip: I get lots of questions about why I place my view models into view extensions, [‚Ä¶]. This is a small app, but think about how this would look when you have 10 views, or 50 views, or even 500 views. If you use extensions like this, the view model for your current view is always just called ViewModel, and not EditMapLocationViewModel or similar ‚Äì it’s much shorter, and avoids cluttering up your code with lots of different class names!

Hm, I‚Äôm not 100% convinced‚Ä¶ #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Today we refactored our code to use MVVM and added ‚Äúunlock with FaceID‚Äù to this part of the app. From [Day 72](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/introducing-mvvm-into-your-swiftui-project): > Tip: I get lots of questions about why I place my view models into view extensions, [‚Ä¶]. This is a small app, but think about how this would look when you have 10 views, or 50 views, or even 500 views. If you use extensions like this, the view model for your current view is always just called ViewModel, and not EditMapLocationViewModel or similar ‚Äì it's much shorter, and avoids cluttering up your code with lots of different class names! Hm, I‚Äôm not 100% convinced‚Ä¶ #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 71, we used Wikipedia‚Äôs API to fetch places near a set of coordinates. I had no idea this was a thing, and I already have an existing app idea that I think could leverage this. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 71, we used Wikipedia‚Äôs API to fetch places near a set of coordinates. I had no idea this was a thing, and I already have an existing app idea that I think could leverage this. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 70 we added the ability to pin locations on a map and edit them.

We were supposed to use .onLongPressGesture, but I couldn‚Äôt get it to work in the previews or simulator, so I just used another .onTapGesture. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 70 we added the ability to pin locations on a map and edit them. We were supposed to use `.onLongPressGesture`, but I couldn‚Äôt get it to work in the previews or simulator, so I just used another `.onTapGesture`. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 69 was short: we learned how to 1) add different types of maps and 2) use Face ID to unlock the app. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 69 was short: we learned how to 1) add different types of maps and 2) use Face ID to unlock the app. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 68 has been some of the most interesting content (from a language-learning perspective) in a while.

First, yes the method is just called <, which is the ‚Äúless than‚Äù operator. It‚Äôs the job of the method to decide whether one user is ‚Äúless than‚Äù (in a sorting sense) another, so we‚Äôre adding functionality to an existing operator. This is called operator overloading, and it can be both a blessing and a curse.

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever worked in a language with operator overloading and it definitely makes me nervous about maintainability. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 68 has been some of the most interesting content (from a language-learning perspective) in a while. > First, yes the method is just called `<`, which is the ‚Äúless than‚Äù operator. It‚Äôs the job of the method to decide whether one user is ‚Äúless than‚Äù (in a sorting sense) another, so we‚Äôre adding functionality to an existing operator. This is called _operator overloading_, and it can be both a blessing and a curse. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever worked in a language with operator overloading and it definitely makes me nervous about maintainability. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 67 is the last day for this particular project, so we had a review quiz (got 12/12) and added some features to the app without any code prompts, just requirements.

I‚Äôm always a little nervous when the challenges are easy‚Ä¶ what did I miss? üòÖ #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 67 is the last day for this particular project, so we had a review quiz (got 12/12) and added some features to the app without any code prompts, just requirements. I‚Äôm always a little nervous when the challenges are easy‚Ä¶ what did I miss? üòÖ #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Back at it after a little Thanksgiving break and we‚Äôve run into our first (I think) need to use @MainActor.

Today we added the ability to change image filters and share the resulting image. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Back at it after a little Thanksgiving break and we‚Äôve run into our first (I think) need to use `@MainActor`. Today we added the ability to change image filters and share the resulting image. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 65 and this sort of thing still gets me:

We can then call that whenever our selectedItem property changes, by attaching an onChange() modifier somewhere in ContentView ‚Äì it really doesn‚Äôt matter where, but attaching it to the PhotosPicker would seem sensible.

We covered modifiers and building our own much earlier in the course, but I still don‚Äôt have a good mental model for how/why you can put some of them anywhere and they‚Äôll work. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 65 and this sort of thing still gets me: > We can then call that whenever our `selectedItem` property changes, by attaching an `onChange()` modifier somewhere in `ContentView` ‚Äì it really doesn‚Äôt matter where, but attaching it to the `PhotosPicker` would seem sensible. We covered modifiers and building our own much earlier in the course, but I still don‚Äôt have a good mental model for how/why you can put some of them anywhere and they‚Äôll work. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 64 we learned how to use PhotosPicker to‚Ä¶ let the user pick photos, use ShareLink to‚Ä¶ create share links, and call requestReview() to‚Ä¶ request the user leave a review of our app! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 64 we learned how to use `PhotosPicker` to‚Ä¶ let the user pick photos, use `ShareLink` to‚Ä¶ create share links, and call `requestReview()` to‚Ä¶ request the user leave a review of our app! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 63, we learned about the different Image APIs available: Image, UIImage, CGImage, and CIImage. We also tried out ContentUnavailableView!

I continued my normal practice of keeping all the sample code in the project and building UI to see it all. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 63, we learned about the different Image APIs available: `Image`, `UIImage`, `CGImage`, and `CIImage`. We also tried out `ContentUnavailableView`! I continued my normal practice of keeping *all* the sample code in the project and building UI to see it all. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 62, I liked that we were shown ‚ÄúOpen Quickly‚Äù in Xcode and told how to find the definition of a generated interface. I don‚Äôt fully understand it now, but I know I will in a couple years.

Oh, and for the start of a new project, we played around with confirmationDialog(). #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 62, I liked that we were shown ‚ÄúOpen Quickly‚Äù in Xcode and told how to find the definition of a generated interface. I don‚Äôt fully understand it now, but I know I will in a couple years. Oh, and for the start of a new project, we played around with `confirmationDialog()`. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Nope, today was the hardest challenge.

I thought it was weird that yesterday‚Äôs challenge didn‚Äôt require us to use SwiftData (when we had just spent a bunch of days working with it).

Day 61, the other shoe drops‚Äîwe need to rewrite yesterday‚Äôs app to use SwiftData. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Nope, *today* was the hardest challenge.

I thought it was weird that yesterday‚Äôs challenge didn‚Äôt require us to use SwiftData (when we had just spent a bunch of days working with it).

[Day 61](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/61), the other shoe drops‚Äîwe need to rewrite yesterday‚Äôs app to use SwiftData. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I thought yesterday was our most difficult day so far‚Ä¶ now Day 60 has surpassed it.

Today we built an app from scratch with just some requirements to fetch data and build a couple views. Straightforward but a lot of work! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: I thought yesterday was our most difficult day so far‚Ä¶ now Day 60 has surpassed it. Today we built an app from scratch with just [some requirements](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/guide/ios-swiftui/5/3/challenge) to fetch data and build a couple views. Straightforward but a lot of work! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Wow, I‚Äôm impressed with myself for learning and SwiftData/SwiftUI for being easy.

For Day 59, we had to go back to an old app and upgrade it to use SwiftData, add sorting, and add filtering. It took me about an hour to do everything, which is a lot faster than I expected. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Wow, I‚Äôm impressed with myself for learning and SwiftData/SwiftUI for being easy. For Day 59, we had to go back to an old app and upgrade it to use SwiftData, add sorting, and add filtering. It took me about an hour to do everything, which is a lot faster than I expected. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 58: Continuing yesterday‚Äôs project and learning about NSPredicate, changing fetch requests dynamically, and creating relationships. One of today‚Äôs sections is about syncing SwiftData with CloudKit, but I skipped it because I don‚Äôt have a paid developer account (yet)! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 58: Continuing yesterday‚Äôs project and learning about NSPredicate, changing fetch requests dynamically, and creating relationships. One of today‚Äôs sections is about [syncing SwiftData with CloudKit](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/syncing-swiftdata-with-cloudkit), but I skipped it because I don‚Äôt have a paid developer account (yet)! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Starting a new project for Day 57, so don‚Äôt have much to show so far. We‚Äôre learning how to edit SwiftData objects with SwiftUI and filter data using #Predicate. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Starting a new project for Day 57, so don‚Äôt have much to show so far. We‚Äôre learning how to edit SwiftData objects with SwiftUI and filter data using `#Predicate`. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 56 was a review and challenge (on our own) day, so I updated the detail view to handle missing data more gracefully. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 56 was a review and challenge (on our own) day, so I updated the detail view to handle missing data more gracefully. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: For Day 55 we learned how to delete SwiftData objects, sort queries using SortDescriptor, and add custom buttons to alerts. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 55 we learned how to delete SwiftData objects, sort queries using `SortDescriptor`, and add custom buttons to alerts. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
For Day 54, we earnestly started the implementation of a ‚ÄúBookworm‚Äù app and created new SwiftData models and SwiftUI components.

I think the only new APIs were .constant() and using .buttonStyle(.plain) to disable the whole ‚Äútap the row to trigger its buttons‚Äù behavior. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: For Day 54, we earnestly started the implementation of a ‚ÄúBookworm‚Äù app and created new SwiftData models and SwiftUI components. I think the only new APIs were [`.constant()`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/binding/constant(_:)) and using `.buttonStyle(.plain)` to disable the whole ‚Äútap the row to trigger its buttons‚Äù behavior. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 53 is the start of our first project with SwiftData. So far all the terminology reminds me of my Core Data days. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 53 is the start of our first project with SwiftData. So far all the terminology reminds me of my Core Data days. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html: Day 52 is a review quiz and challenge day. I found the challenges pretty easy this time around! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Day 52 is a review quiz and challenge day. I found the challenges pretty easy this time around! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
It‚Äôs our first day using the debugger! I love debuggers so much. I feel like teaching how to use real debuggers is undervalued by the developer community.

Day 51, officially over half-way done with #100DaysOfSwiftUI!

Day 46 was a review quiz and a challenge!

Today is the first day I‚Äôve run into this error (that I‚Äôve seen so many SwiftUI developers complain about):

The compiler is unable to type-check this expression in reasonable time; try breaking up the expression into distinct sub-expressions

Does that make me a real SwiftUI dev now? #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 37, using the APIs we learned yesterday in a new app, but this stood out to me (emphasis mine):

First, we need to decide what an expense is ‚Äì what do we want it to store? In this instance it will be three things: the name of the item, whether it‚Äôs business or personal, and its cost as a Double.

In a real app, you should almost always keep prices as integers so math with them is accurate.

As a training creator, I know there‚Äôs a trade-off between having ‚Äúproduction-ready‚Äù code vs. simplifying it for learning.

This is a case where I would have made a different decision. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Day 37, using the APIs we learned yesterday in a new app, but this stood out to me (emphasis mine):

> First, we need to decide what an expense is ‚Äì what do we want it to store? In this instance it will be three things: the name of the item, whether it‚Äôs business or personal, and its _cost as a `Double`._

In a real app, you should almost always keep prices as integers so math with them is accurate.

As a training creator, I know there‚Äôs a trade-off between having ‚Äúproduction-ready‚Äù code vs. simplifying it for learning.

This is a case where I would have made a different decision. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 36 is the start of a new project, and thus a day of learning new APIs: @Observable with class, .sheet(), @Environment, .onDelete(), UserDefaults / @AppStorage, Codable, and JSONEncoder.

I would‚Äôve liked more info about @Environment but I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll get into it more soon. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

I would‚Äôve liked more info about `@Environment` but I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll get into it more soon. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Day 29 is bringing me back to my Objective-C days:

let range = checker.rangeOfMisspelledWord(in: word, range: range, startingAt: 0, wrap: false, language: "en")

The full rangeOfMisspelledWordInString:range:startingAt:wrap:language: API signature is too long for this post. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Day 29 is bringing me back to my Objective-C days:

```swift
let range = checker.rangeOfMisspelledWord(in: word, range: range, startingAt: 0, wrap: false, language: "en")
```

The full [`rangeOfMisspelledWordInString:range:startingAt:wrap:language:`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uitextchecker/1621029-rangeofmisspelledwordinstring?language=objc) API signature is too long for this post. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I realize that you might have thought ‚Äúwow, we‚Äôre looking at machine learning already?‚Äù After all, this is only day 27 of a 100-day course. But, as Andre Gide said, ‚Äúyou cannot discover new oceans unless you have the courage to lose sight of the shore.‚Äù

Heh, #100DaysOfSwiftUI read my mind!

Today we built a UI on top of the Core ML model we trained yesterday. Straightforward but fun!

Today we built a UI on top of the Core ML model we trained yesterday. Straightforward but fun!

items.content_html:
Today I learned that the order of modifiers does matter:

Text("Hello, world!")
    .padding()
    .background(.red)
    .padding()
    .background(.blue)
    .padding()
    .background(.green)
    .padding()
    .background(.yellow)

Day 23 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Today I learned that the order of modifiers does matter: ```swift Text("Hello, world!") .padding() .background(.red) .padding() .background(.blue) .padding() .background(.green) .padding() .background(.yellow) ``` Day 23 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This definitely trips me up:

Tip: It‚Äôs tempting to think that modifier should be attached to the end of the NavigationStack, but it needs to be attached to the end of the Form instead. The reason is that navigation stacks are capable of showing many views as your program runs, so by attaching the title to the thing inside the navigation stack we‚Äôre allowing iOS to change titles freely.

I‚Äôm not sure I 100% understand the reasoning here‚Ä¶ excited to learn more. It‚Äôs still only day 17! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This definitely trips me up:

> Tip: It‚Äôs tempting to think that modifier should be attached to the end of the `NavigationStack`, but it needs to be attached to the end of the `Form` instead. The reason is that navigation stacks are capable of showing many views as your program runs, so by attaching the title to the thing inside the navigation stack we‚Äôre allowing iOS to change titles freely.

I‚Äôm not sure I 100% understand the reasoning here‚Ä¶ excited to learn more. It‚Äôs still only day 17! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I have a lot to learn about what enables this syntax for two-way binding (note the $):

struct ContentView: View {
    @State private var name = ""

    var body: some View {
        Form {
            TextField("Enter your name", text: $name)
            Text("Hello, world!")
        }
    }
}

items.content_html:
Day 14 is optionals, guards, nil coalescing, optional chaining, and optional try.

Guards are new to me but I like them:

func double(number: Int?) -> Int? {
	guard let number = number else {
		return nil
	}
	return number * 2
}

Two weeks in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
My Series 10 has had really inconsistent battery life (it died on me 8 miles into a run last week üôÉ) so I‚Äôm happy to see potential fixes in this watchOS update.

items.content_html: Prototypes, opaque return types, extensions, and protocol extensions don‚Äôt have equivalents in JavaScript (and my TypeScript isn‚Äôt good enough to compare Swift to TS), but these concepts were straightforward enough that I breezed through day 13. #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Prototypes, opaque return types, extensions, and protocol extensions don‚Äôt have equivalents in JavaScript (and my TypeScript isn‚Äôt good enough to compare Swift to TS), but these concepts were straightforward enough that I breezed through day 13. #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
copies of the same class share their underlying data, meaning that changing one changes them all, whereas structs always have their own unique data, and changing a copy does not affect the others.

I found this explanation confusing until I took the test and realized the difference.

In JS, creating an object or class instance and assigning it to two different variables matches the ‚Äúcopy‚Äù semantics above (the variable is a reference to the object).

The ‚Äústruct‚Äù behavior (by value) is how primitives work in JS (string, bool, etc.). Objects never work this way.

Day 12 over! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
> copies of the same class share their underlying data, meaning that changing one changes them all, whereas structs always have their own unique data, and changing a copy does not affect the others.

I found this explanation confusing until I took the test and realized the difference.

In JS, creating an object or class instance and assigning it to two different variables matches the ‚Äúcopy‚Äù semantics above (the variable is a reference to the object).

The ‚Äústruct‚Äù behavior (by value) is how primitives work in JS (string, bool, etc.). Objects never work this way.

Day 12 over! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Dropping the parenthesis when calling functions with a closure blows my mind:

team.filter { $0.hasPrefix("T") }

The equivalent in JS:

team.filter($0 => $0.startsWith("T"))

Woo! The checkpoint test actually didn‚Äôt take me very long to complete.

Day 9 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Dropping the parenthesis when calling functions with a closure blows my mind:

```swift
team.filter { $0.hasPrefix("T") }
```

The equivalent in JS:

```js
team.filter($0 => $0.startsWith("T"))
```

Woo! The checkpoint test actually didn‚Äôt take me very long to complete.

Day 9 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Really interesting that Swift has do, but it‚Äôs not what you think!

do {
    try throwingFunction1()
    nonThrowingFunction1()
} catch {
    print("Handle errors here")
}

In JS, that do would be try and no ‚Äútry‚Äù is required before a throwing function.

Day 8 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

Awesome to me that this is valid:

func record(age: Int) { }
func record(year: Int) { }

Naming internal and external parameters separately is interesting too:

func square(of num: Int) -> Int {
    return num * num
}

let result = square(of: 4)

Day 7 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

Day 6 is all about for and while loops.

I‚Äôll be excited to learn the .map and .filter equivalents. I rarely use for loops in JS and have only used while a couple times in my career. ü´¢

I wasn‚Äôt expecting to do FizzBuzz for the checkpoint test. There‚Äôs a first time for everything! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Day 6 is all about `for` and `while` loops.

I‚Äôll be excited to learn the `.map` and `.filter` equivalents. I rarely use `for` loops in JS and have only used `while` a couple times in my career. ü´¢

I wasn‚Äôt expecting to do FizzBuzz for the checkpoint test. There‚Äôs a first time for everything! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
My comment about no === in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184
items.content_text:
My comment about no `===` in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184

items.content_html:
No === in Swift (just ==) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And switch statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs fallthrough syntax seems much safer than JS needing a break for each case.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
No `===` in Swift (just `==`) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And `switch` statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs `fallthrough` syntax seems much safer than JS needing a `break` for each `case`.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This is really interesting:

let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using const) requires an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This is really interesting:

```swift
let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once
```

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using `const`) _requires_ an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

```swift
let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])
```

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

```swift
let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")
```

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript a lot as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that 1_00__00___00____00 is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
items.content_text:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript *a lot* as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that `1_00__00___00____00` is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
